articles.headline: For Tesla and Musk, Auto Strike Carries Benefits and Risks
articles.snippet: Elon Musk, the Tesla chief executive, may be able to exploit his rivals’ weaknesses, but the United Automobile Workers union also has the electric carmaker in its sights.
articles.abstract: Elon Musk, the Tesla chief executive, may be able to exploit his rivals’ weaknesses, but the United Automobile Workers union also has the electric carmaker in its sights.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers strike against the Michigan automakers would seem to be nothing but good news for Tesla, the electric vehicle maker that has upended the industry and stolen customers from Ford Motor, General Motors and Stellantis, which owns Jeep and Ram.

articles.headline: Are High Rates Going to Last? Fed Officials Increasingly Think So.
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve officials forecast higher interest rates through 2026 this week, a sign that borrowing costs are not heading back to the rock-bottom levels normal before the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve officials forecast higher interest rates through 2026 this week, a sign that borrowing costs are not heading back to the rock-bottom levels normal before the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: The era of ultralow interest rates may be over. At the very least, policymakers don’t expect the type of low borrowing costs that prevailed before the pandemic to return anytime soon.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Biden Faces Competing Pressures as He Tries to Ease the Migrant Crisis
articles.snippet: The situation provides ammunition to conservative Republicans who are vowing to shut down the government unless Congress agrees to strict new anti-immigration measures.
articles.abstract: The situation provides ammunition to conservative Republicans who are vowing to shut down the government unless Congress agrees to strict new anti-immigration measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: The demand that President Biden ease the migrant crisis threatening to overwhelm American cities came privately, from the New York governor to top White House officials. It came publicly, in angry statements from Democratic and Republican officials around the country. It came from scores of immigrant rights groups.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Luis Ferré-Sadurní

articles.headline: Lachlan Murdoch’s On-Again, Off-Again Relationship With the Family Business
articles.snippet: He solidified his rise to the top of his father’s media empire on Thursday.
articles.abstract: He solidified his rise to the top of his father’s media empire on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lachlan Murdoch’s path to succession has been rocky at times, but he is finally getting the family prize: sole possession of the keys to his father’s media empire.
articles.byline: By Katie Robertson and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Inside the Deal to Free 5 American Prisoners in Iran
articles.snippet: U.S. negotiators say the release of the prisoners is proof that even fierce adversaries can sometimes find their way to an agreement. But the deal almost didn’t happen.
articles.abstract: U.S. negotiators say the release of the prisoners is proof that even fierce adversaries can sometimes find their way to an agreement. But the deal almost didn’t happen.
articles.lead_paragraph: The prisoner swap was all arranged, or so the American negotiators thought.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: Real Estate Crisis Triggers New Alarms Over China’s Shadow Banks
articles.snippet: A financially troubled firm has stopped paying investors, risking panic and testing the Chinese government’s resolve to take on debts from its property crisis.
articles.abstract: A financially troubled firm has stopped paying investors, risking panic and testing the Chinese government’s resolve to take on debts from its property crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: An accountant in northeast China deposited her life savings and received a letter guaranteeing her investment in a trust firm. Workers at a state-owned utility pooled money from friends and relatives believing that their investments were backed by the government. A man sank $140,000 into an account that he was told would make a 10.1 percent annual return.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu

articles.headline: Microsoft Closes In on Activision Deal After Britain Signals Approval
articles.snippet: Britain’s antitrust regulator said the companies had addressed its main concerns about the $69 billion deal, though final approval is yet to come.
articles.abstract: Britain’s antitrust regulator said the companies had addressed its main concerns about the $69 billion deal, though final approval is yet to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft came one step closer on Friday to completing its $69 billion purchase of the video game maker Activision Blizzard, in a deal that has become an example of how a company can successfully ride out stricter regulatory scrutiny of the power of tech giants.

articles.headline: For South Korea’s Senior Subway Riders, the Joy Is in the Journey
articles.snippet: The fare is free for those older than 65, and so some retired people spend their days riding the trains to the end of the line.
articles.abstract: The fare is free for those older than 65, and so some retired people spend their days riding the trains to the end of the line.
articles.lead_paragraph: The subway rumbled toward its final stop north of Seoul. Along the way, hordes disembarked, with the determined, brisk gait of those with somewhere to be.
articles.byline: By Victoria Kim and Chang W. Lee

articles.headline: Gold’s Deadly Truth: Much Is Mined With Mercury
articles.snippet: Ten years after an international treaty to ban mercury, the toxic metal continues to poison. The reason might have to do with your wedding ring.
articles.abstract: Ten years after an international treaty to ban mercury, the toxic metal continues to poison. The reason might have to do with your wedding ring.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeovane de Jesus Aguiar was knee-deep in mud in the 100-yard gash he had cut into the Amazon rainforest, filtering brown water out of a pan, when he found the small, shiny flake he was looking for: a mixture of gold and mercury.
articles.byline: By Fabian Federl, Jack Nicas and Ian Cheibub

articles.headline: For Many Big Food Companies, Emissions Head in the Wrong Direction
articles.snippet: Several of the world’s largest food and restaurant companies have not made progress on their goal to cut greenhouse gas emissions. Some are even producing more.
articles.abstract: Several of the world’s largest food and restaurant companies have not made progress on their goal to cut greenhouse gas emissions. Some are even producing more.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years ago McDonald’s said it planned to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by more than a third in parts of its operations by 2030. A few years later, it pledged to be “net zero” — cutting emissions to as close to zero as possible — by 2050.

articles.headline: What Happens When the Boss Invites You to Bible Study?
articles.snippet: Secular companies have invited employees to bring their “whole selves” to work. That increasingly includes their religion.
articles.abstract: Secular companies have invited employees to bring their “whole selves” to work. That increasingly includes their religion.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Christy Childers moved from Austin to San Francisco in 2017 to start a marketing job at Facebook, she felt anxious about sharing her evangelical faith with her new colleagues. In Ms. Childers’s religious community, Silicon Valley has a reputation for being overtly secular and less than accepting of Christian beliefs. She now calls that view “unfounded.” Within a week, colleagues had invited her to a lunchtime Bible study and a happy hour attended by scores of Christians across the tech industry.

articles.headline: U.A.W. Widens Strikes at G.M. and Stellantis, but Cites Progress in Ford Talks
articles.snippet: The union designated 38 spare-parts distribution centers as additional strike targets at General Motors and Stellantis.
articles.abstract: The union designated 38 spare-parts distribution centers as additional strike targets at General Motors and Stellantis.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers union on Friday significantly raised the pressure on General Motors and Stellantis, the parent of Jeep and Ram, by expanding its strike against the companies to include all the spare-parts distribution centers of the two companies.

articles.headline: Push to Gag Trump Pits Free Speech Against Risk of Violence
articles.snippet: By putting threats to the judge and prosecutors at the heart of its argument to limit the former president’s statements about the election case, the Justice Department raised issues with little precedent.
articles.abstract: By putting threats to the judge and prosecutors at the heart of its argument to limit the former president’s statements about the election case, the Justice Department raised issues with little precedent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The request by prosecutors that a judge impose a gag order on former President Donald J. Trump in the federal election-subversion case presents a thorny conflict between the scope of his First Amendment rights and fears that he could — intentionally or not — spur his supporters to violence.
